author: KTVU staff
title: Storm surge, high surf forces Santa Cruz beaches to close, Stinson Beach evacuation
text:
Marin County sees evacuation orders lifted in some areas In Marin County, evacuation orders have been canceled for areas around Stinson Beach. Earlier Thursday, some communities near the beach were told to be ready to go due to high surf and storm surge.
SANTA CRUZ, Calif. - The Bay Area's beach towns got hammered on Thursday as high surf and storm surges ravaged the coastline.
Around Santa Cruz, seaside streets were littered with debris, soaked with flooding, and battered by big waves. The city closed the Santa Cruz Wharf, Main Beach and Cowell Beach because of the massive waves and resulting damage.
At Rio Del Mar State Beach in Santa Cruz, logs littered the sandy coast and onlookers sat on perches witnessing Mother Nature in action.
In addition, West Cliff in Santa Cruz was also closed between Columbia and David Way. The iconic road is still being repaired from last year's storms.
Meanwhile, in Pacifica, a pair of crab fishers arrived at Linda Mar Beach and then turned around to go home.
"Apparently, that's not going to happen," Paul Gonzales said. "But the pier's closed. These waves are outrageous."
Steve Ramirez sighed and said: "We're just going to pack up."
High surf warnings and advisories are in effect along the entire California coast as waves are expected to break up to 40 feet high. As of Thursday afternoon, reports from the Bay Area's coastal buoys were showing waves just under 30 feet off both the Sonoma County coast and Monterey Bay.
Huge low-pressure systems in the Pacific Ocean are pushing large groups of waves toward the California coast.
The National Weather Service reported that its buoy off Bodega Bay recorded waves up to 28 feet on Thursday morning, closing in on the previous record of 31 feet seen during January storms at the beginning of the year.
Evacuation warnings lifted after high surf and flooding shut down Santa Cruz, coastal areas Around Santa Cruz, seaside streets were littered with debris, soaked with flooding, and battered by big waves. The city closed the Santa Cruz Wharf, Main Beach and Cowell Beach because of the massive waves and resulting damage.
At Rio Del Mar Beach, the waves crashed over walls, flooding streets, and depositing massive trees and driftwood ashore.
"The trees act like battering rams against the houses and the garage doors that are along the street here," says resident, Steve Benedetti.
Residents in Santa Cruz County know the danger all too well. So do the authorities. But they worried about the tourists.
"We do have visitors from out of town that may not have been expecting this kind of tidal surge during their visit. So we did have deputies out here very early going door to door explaining to people hey this is coming," says Ashley Keehn, public information officer with the Santa Cruz County Sheriff's Office.
Early in the morning, the Stinson Beach Fire Department issued an evacuation order for several neighborhoods because of high surf as the winds and waves were enormous, telling people they could find a temporary safe harbor at the Stinson Beach Community Center.
The order was issued just before 10 a.m., and people were sent to the Stinson Beach Community Center for refuge. Residents in the Calles Pinos, Pradero, Sierra, Onda Resaca, Ribera, Embarcadero, and sections of Calle Del Arroyo werenâ€™t told to return to their homes until early in the afternoon.
Drone pilot David Golubev shot video of the swell hitting the beach around 11 a.m. and getting dangerously close to houses and buildings along the shoreline.
"Definitely the highest tide Iâ€™ve seen so far. You could see it on the beach. It came up all the way to the top," Golubev said. "I saw it was high tide, and I heard the water so I came out to see how far the water came up."
Officials said the waves reached 10 feet, more than the National Weather Service predicted.
The evacuation order was lifted in the early afternoon when the tide receded.
Stinson Beach Fire Chief Jesse Peri said crews are still assessing the damage in the area and at last count Thursday afternoon one person has minor injuries and a handful of homes suffered minor structural damage.
"The community is really resilient, so they came together to help sandbag and help each other out," said Peri, who reiterated that people should continue to stay away from the water.
Further south in San Francisco, strong swells crashed against San Francisco's Fort Point.
Image 1 of 10 â–¼ Rio Del Mar Esplanade is currently flooded in Santa Cruz on Dec. 28, 2023. Photo: Santa Cruz County

author: PA News Agency
title: Off-road drivers were swept away by river, says man who tried to save them | News Shopper
text:
A man who tried to save three men trapped in a submerged 4Ã—4 vehicle said they were â€œswept awayâ€ as they attempted to cross a river.
Emergency services including police, ambulance and a helicopter attended a location on the River Esk near Glaisdale shortly before midday on Thursday.
A 4Ã—4 was recovered from the river by the fire service just after 3pm and three men found inside had died, North Yorkshire Police said.
Chris Ford, who lives nearby, told the PA news agency the men were part of an off-roading group when they crossed a ford on Rake Lane.
The river, swollen by heavy rain, swept them away and carried them around 400 yards downstream, he said.
Emergency services have been dealing with a serious incident on Thursday (28 December) involving a 4Ã—4 vehicle in the River Esk near Glaisdale on the North York Moors ðŸš¨
Three men sadly died at the scene.
More information is available here â¬‡ï¸ https://t.co/KgxPhHATO4 pic.twitter.com/AvDT3TiqCk
â€” North Yorkshire Police (@NYorksPolice) December 28, 2023
It came as Storm Gerrit caused flooding and travel chaos across the country throughout Wednesday and Thursday.
Mr Ford, a firewood salesman, was called to the scene to help recover the vehicle with his tractor and found it fully submerged beneath the water, he said.
He and two others used tractors to pull the 4Ã—4 on to the riverbank, he said.
Police said another man, who attempted to help those trapped in the car, was pulled from the river and needed medical treatment.
Mr Ford told PA: â€œThere was a ford they were going over and they were swept down 400 yards.
â€œThey were part of an off-road club.
â€œI went down with my tractor. There was a couple of vehicles â€“ one parked up.
â€œYou couldnâ€™t see the (other) vehicle. It was 3ft beneath the water.
â€œI helped get it out on to the riverbank with three other tractors.â€
Two other locals, Rosie and Andrew Dale, said they were with Mr Ford when he got the call to help.
They said they saw several 4Ã—4 vehicles pass their home in the direction of the ford shortly before the incident.
Mrs Dale said â€œnobody localâ€ would attempt to cross the ford in the current conditions.
The area is popular with 4Ã—4 drivers, she said, adding: â€œIn the summer you get 10 of them at a time.â€
NUMBERPLATE PIXELLATED BY PA PICTURE DESK AT REQUEST OF NORTH YORKSHIRE POLICE The recovered vehicle being removed from the River Esk (Danny Lawson/PA) A spokesperson for North Yorkshire Police said: â€œLocalised conditions across our area are making driving hazardous.
â€œRoads are particularly badly affected around the River Esk, to the north of the county, as we have seen with the tragic incident near Glaisdale.
â€œThere was another incident at nearby Houlsyke at 12.49pm when a car got stuck in flood water and another at Kirby Wiske in Hambleton at 2.35pm.
â€œThankfully, the occupants of both vehicles were brought to safety.
â€œThe key advice is to consider whether your journey is necessary.
â€œPlease avoid driving through any kind of standing or moving flood water if you possibly can.â€
Witnesses to the incident at Glaisdale are urged to call North Yorkshire Police on 101, option 4, quoting reference NYP-28122023-0146.

author: ä»£è‰³
title: Italy bears severest weather on record in 2023: reports
text:
A man walks in flood water in Tuscany Region, Italy, Nov 3, 2023. [Photo/Xinhua] ROME -- Italy has experienced a record-setting number of extreme weather events in 2023, a year that is set to be the warmest in more than 150 years, reports said on Thursday.
According to the climate observatory run by the environmental lobby group Legambiente, Italy reported 378 severe weather events in 2023, an increase of 22 percent compared to last year -- ranging from heatwaves to drought and from hailstorms to floods and extreme winds, which were directly responsible for at least 31 deaths.
On the other hand, the agriculture sector union Coldiretti said there were more than nine harsh weather events per day this year across Italy's boot-shaped peninsula.
In its report, Coldiretti estimated that extreme weather caused a record 6 billion euros ($6.6 billion) of damages to crops and agricultural infrastructure, leading to shortfalls in the country's production of olive oil, peaches, nectarines and wheat.
Legambiente said its calculations showed that the northern part of the country was hit the hardest, with 210 separate extreme weather events, followed by 98 in the central regions and 70 in the south which includes the island regions of Sicily and Sardinia.
Among the extreme weather events were floods, record high temperatures, rain-triggered landslides and hailstorms, it said.
Much of Europe suffered a long and dry summer and multiple severe weather events this year, but Italy is often hit harder due to its long coastline and exposure to the sea on two coasts. Meteorological data indicate that this year is set to be the warmest in more than 150 years of record-keeping in Italy.
Meanwhile, weather agencies predict the year will end with an unusually warm spell, with high daytime temperatures across much of the Italian peninsula, assuring that 2024 will start out on the warm side.

author: Alan Halaly
title: Turkeys illegally dumped near Key Pittman Wildlife Management Area | Local Nevada | Local
text:
State wildlife officials are trying to track down two people who illegally released about 25 turkeys about 110 miles north of Las Vegas.
On April 9, officials found the turkeys at Key Pittman Wildlife Management Area, which is home to Nesbitt Lake and more than 24 species of ducks. Itâ€™s also a frequent pit stop for migratory birds.
The turkeys were either domesticated or wild ones that had been captured and fed, Game Division Administrator Shawn Espinosa said in a statement. Either way, they all would have likely been eaten by predators or died from natural causes, he said.
â€œThat brings up a myriad of concerns not the least of which is disease,â€ Espinosa said. â€œThey could have any number of diseases that could be devastating to the wild bird population in the area.â€
Game wardens believe that those responsible are from Clark County because they came from the south and left that way. The wardens found photos of a truck and trailer from a convenience storeâ€™s security footage and are asking the public to notify them with any information.
â€œAny information could be key to this investigation,â€ Game Warden Lieutenant John Anderson said in a statement.
To provide information to the Nevada Department of Wildlife, people may call its hotline at 1-800-992-3030 or submit an anonymous tip using the departmentâ€™s Tip app, available for download on any mobile device.
Contact Alan at ahalaly@reviewjournal.com. Follow @AlanHalaly on X.

author: Semana
title: Trabajadora de Van Camps desmiente a MinTrabajo: "Es mentira lo que se diceâ€
text: En todo un cruce de declaraciones se ha convertido la denuncia presentada por la ministra del Trabajo, Gloria InÃ©s RamÃ­rez , en la que seÃ±ala a la compaÃ±Ã­a condiciones en las que estas mujeres ejercen sus labores no son las mejores . Por ejemplo, no tienen el tiempo para ir al baÃ±oâ€. Ese relato contrasta con la afirmaciÃ³n de Guardado Castro, quien dijo: â€œ De paso invito a la ministra para que venga aquÃ­ a nuestra planta, para que vea cÃ³mo se trabaja aquÃ­, y para que mire, se cerciore, y ella pueda mirar que es mentira todo lo que se diceâ€. La denuncia contra Van Campâ€™s surgiÃ³ a partir de la visita del Ministerio del Trabajo a esa empresa y del relato de la trabajadora Alicia Cardiles , quien dio el testimonio afirmando que sus empleadores les estarÃ­an descontando de su salario laboral el tiempo que se tardan en ir al baÃ±o.Cardiles asegurÃ³ que â€œesta empresa nos estÃ¡ obligando a utilizar paÃ±os desechables porque nos descuentan en los salarios la ida al baÃ±o . Eso nos estÃ¡ produciendo, a futuro, enfermedades a nuestro aparato reproductor, infecciones urinarias que a futuro se nos puede volver cÃ¡ncer. Entonces, por eso, no mÃ¡s violaciÃ³n a los derechos de las mujeresâ€.Pues bien, la versiÃ³n de esa colaboradora de Van Campâ€™s contrasta con el testimonio de Marta LucÃ­a Guardado Castro, quien la seÃ±alÃ³ directamente de estar mintiendo. â€œAsÃ­ que la invito nuevamente a la ministra. Llegue aquÃ­ a nuestra planta, que la atendemos con mucho cariÃ±o, para que usted vea cÃ³mo se trabaja aquÃ­ en la familia Van Campâ€™sâ€, sostuvo la mujer que seÃ±alÃ³ a Alicia Cardiles de estar mintiendo en su denuncia.El Ministerio del Trabajo hizo pÃºblica su denuncia sobre los casos de acoso laboral que habrÃ­a encontrado en empresas pesqueras y de flores que se enfocan en contratar mujeres como su principal mano de obra. No obstante, hasta el mediodÃ­a de este jueves (28 de diciembre) no habÃ­a presentado pruebas al respecto.La compaÃ±Ã­a Seatech Internacional Inc., que tiene la planta de atÃºn en Cartagena, desmintiÃ³ lo publicado por la funcionaria Gloria InÃ©s RamÃ­rez y anunciÃ³ que tomarÃ¡ acciones legales contra el Gobierno.SegÃºn dijo esa corporaciÃ³n en un comunicado, â€œla compaÃ±Ã­a y sus 1.800 colaboradores reiteran que lo seÃ±alado no es cierto y procederÃ¡ a defenderse de este ataque bajo, conforme a la leyâ€. Otra versiÃ³n que saliÃ³ a flote en medio del cruce de declaraciones entre el Gobierno, la empresa y las trabajadoras de Van Campâ€™s, fue la del sindicato Sintramar Cartagena, que publicÃ³ un comunicado en el que detallÃ³ que â€œno es cierto que a las trabajadoras no se les deja ir al baÃ±o a hacer sus necesidades. No sabemos de dÃ³nde saliÃ³ esa informaciÃ³n que a todas luces es malintencionadaâ€.

author: Keri Brenner
title: Marin educators, nonprofit develop health career training program
text:
Marin high school students interested in a career in health care could receive early professional training from a program to be launched next year.
The pilot course, to be offered in the spring at San Marin High School in Novato, is being developed by the Marin County Office of Education, the Novato Unified School District and By the Bay Health, a nonprofit regional hospice program based in Larkspur.â€œWe are excited to partner with By the Bay Health, one of the most innovative health care providers in Marin County, on this critical initiative to develop a thriving health care workforce to adequately support our growing community,â€ said John Carroll, the county superintendent of schools.â€œIntroducing students at an earlier age to the diversity of options in the health care field is key,â€ Carroll said. â€œBy bringing real-world experience and clinical expertise into the classroom, we can expose students to additional career options that will create a tangible impact in our community.â€The program, called â€œIntroduction to the World of Healthcare,â€ will be offered as an elective to 11th and 12th graders at San Marin High School. The curriculum will include subjects such as medical ethics, public health and emerging trends in the profession, according to Jesse Madsen, a career education administrator at the county office.The program will also include hands-on skill practice, role playing, field trips and certification opportunities, Madsen said.The effort is the first step in By the Bay Healthâ€™s plan to create â€œa public and academic partnership aiming to raise $1 million to develop a skilled, compassionate workforce to serve the North Bayâ€™s aging population,â€ Madsen said.â€œOur biggest barrier to ensuring access to high quality, accessible care in the home to meet the needs of an increasingly diverse and growing population of children and adults in Marin County is recruiting exceptional talent,â€ said Skelly Wingard, chief executive officer at By the Bay Health. â€œWe are optimistic this partnership with MCOE will inspire more students to join the
continuum of care â€” particularly in areas like home-based palliative care, hospice care and home health care.â€Tracy Smith, superintendent of the Novato Unified School District, said the district is â€œthrilledâ€ to be a part of the project.â€œStudents are hungry for knowledge about careers where they can find meaning and purpose,â€ Smith said. â€œBased on the positive reception to the new course, weâ€™re excited to support this initiative to build more interest in growing fields such as health care.â€Madsen said the program will add to related medical career classes at Novato and Terra Linda high schools.In addition to general health care training, the program will have an added focus on nursing and home health professionals. Those workers are in short supply in Marin and throughout the Bay Area, Madsen said.â€œBy 2030, Californiaâ€™s population of individuals aged 65 and older will reach 9 million, nearly 20% of the stateâ€™s residents,â€ Madsen said. â€œMarin County ranks 13th in the state for this age demographic at 22.3%.â€The pilot program could also offer a model of how Marin employers and K-12 schools could work together to provide courses within the school day that lead to â€œhigh-demand, livable-wage careers,â€ Madsen said.â€œWe think this model can be replicated with additional local health care providers and employers in other industry sectors, supporting the development of a homegrown workforce and expanding career pathway opportunities for our students,â€ he said.By the Bay Health, a nonprofit affiliate of UCSF Health, operates in Marin, San Francisco, San Mateo, Sonoma, Alameda, Napa and Solano counties. The organization offers hospice and skilled home health care, palliative care, grief support and pediatric care.

author: Bangkok Post Public Company Limited
title: Ministry to address foreign tourists' complaints on Learning page Bangkok Post Learning - Learn English from News
text:
Higher admission prices for foreigners at countless attractions across Thailand are a longtime complaint. The Ministry of Tourism and Sports has pledged to address concerns raised by foreign tourists, including dual pricing, following recent complaints on the Bangkok Post Learning Facebook page.
Minister Sorawong Thienthong made the pledge after a meeting prompted by a social media article titled â€œWhere Have Foreign Tourists Gone?â€ published on April 24. The article compiled and translated into Thai the views of foreign tourists and expatriates in response to a story in the Bangkok Post.
The news story, â€œThailand faces lower tourist numbersâ€, was also published on April 22 on the Facebook page of Bangkok Post Learning, where it drew more than 1,800 comments about a variety of issues .
The views highlighted concerns about safety, assault , overcharging, threats from transnational criminal groups in tourist areas, and extortion â€” factors that may be contributing to the decline in international arrivals to Thailand.
Mr Sorawong said that every case involving foreign tourists will now be reported directly from the police to him.
Tourists can submit requests for help via the Thailand Tourist Police application, and a tourist assistance centre has been set up in every province to support visitors.
Responding to complaints about expensive accommodation, he said that this is often due to seasonal price adjustments, while the rise in airfares is a global issue that has been caused by a shortage of aircraft.
The ministry has pledged to address tourism scams and ensure fair prices for both Thai and foreign tourists, which means the dual-pricing system will be eliminated, said Mr Sorawong.
Vocabulary assault : attacking someone violently - à¸à¸²à¸£à¸—à¸³à¸£à¹‰à¸²à¸¢à¸£à¹ˆà¸²à¸‡à¸à¸²à¸¢ complaint : when someone says that something is wrong or not satisfactory - à¸à¸²à¸£à¸£à¹‰à¸­à¸‡à¹€à¸£à¸µà¸¢à¸™ dual-pricing : charging one group of people a different price than another - eliminate : to get rid of completely - à¸à¸³à¸ˆà¸±à¸”à¸«à¸£à¸·à¸­à¸‚à¸ˆà¸±à¸”à¹ƒà¸«à¹‰à¸«à¸¡à¸”à¹„à¸› expatriate (expat) : a person living in a country that is not their own - à¸„à¸™à¸—à¸µà¹ˆà¸­à¸²à¸¨à¸±à¸¢à¸­à¸¢à¸¹à¹ˆà¸•à¹ˆà¸²à¸‡à¸›à¸£à¸°à¹€à¸—à¸¨ (à¹€à¸›à¹‡à¸™à¹€à¸§à¸¥à¸²à¸™à¸²à¸™) extortion : the crime of trying to obtain something by force or threat - à¸à¸²à¸£à¸‚à¸¹à¹ˆà¸à¸£à¸£à¹‚à¸Šà¸ à¸£à¸µà¸”à¹„à¸– issue : a problem that needs to be considered - à¸›à¸£à¸°à¹€à¸”à¹‡à¸™ overcharge (verb) : to ask for too much money for the product or service you are selling - à¸„à¸´à¸”à¹€à¸‡à¸´à¸™à¹à¸žà¸‡à¹€à¸à¸´à¸™à¹„à¸› pledge : a serious promise - à¸„à¸³à¸¡à¸±à¹ˆà¹‰à¸™à¸ªà¸±à¸à¸à¸² pledge : to make a serious promise to do something - à¸ªà¸±à¸à¸à¸² prompted : caused - à¸à¹ˆà¸­à¹ƒà¸«à¹‰à¹€à¸à¸´à¸” scam : a dishonest plan, especially for getting money - à¸à¸¥à¹‚à¸à¸‡, à¹à¸œà¸™à¸£à¹‰à¸²à¸¢ seasonal : typical of or suitable for the time of year - à¸•à¸²à¸¡à¸¤à¸”à¸¹à¸à¸²à¸¥ threat : a danger - à¸­à¸±à¸™à¸•à¸£à¸²à¸¢ transnational : involving more than one country; present in more than one country - à¸‚à¹‰à¸²à¸¡à¸Šà¸²à¸•à¸´
